verb.description: Produce (a picture or diagram) by making lines and marks, especially with a pen or pencil, on paper.
Pull or drag (something such as a vehicle) so as to make it follow behind.
examples: a cart drawn by two horses

verb.description: Take or obtain (liquid) from a container or receptacle.
examples: he drew his gun and peered into the gloomy apartment
the children went down to the pond to draw water
the syringe drew off most of the fluid
he met them with a drawn sword

verb.description: Be the cause of (a specified response)
examples: he drew criticism for his lavish spending

verb.description: Select (a ticket or name) randomly to decide winners in a lottery, opponents in a sporting contest, etc.
examples: she drew a ticket and announced the number but no one claimed it

verb.description: Finish (a contest or game) with an even score; tie.
examples: Brazil had drawn a stormy match 1–1

verb.description: Hit (the ball) so that it travels slightly to the left (for a left-handed player, the right), usually as a result of spin given to the ball.
examples: he had to learn to draw the ball—not least for the tee shots at Augusta

verb.description: Impart backspin to (the cue ball), making it move backwards after hitting an object ball.
(of a ship) require (a specified depth of water) to float in; have (a certain draft)
examples: boats that draw only a few inches of water

verb.description: (of a sail) be filled with wind.
Extract (an object) from a container or receptacle.
examples: he drew his gun and peered into the gloomy apartment

noun.description: An act of selecting names randomly, typically by extracting them from a bag or other container, to match competitors in a game or tournament.
examples: the draw has been made for this year's tournament

noun.description: A game or contest that ends with the score even; a tie.
A person or thing that is very attractive or interesting.
examples: the museum has turned out to be a big draw for schoolchildren in the city

noun.description: An act of removing a gun from its holster in order to shoot.
A shot causing the ball to deviate to the left (or, for a left-handed golfer, the right).
An act of inhaling smoke from a cigarette or cigar.
examples: superb cigars offering tons of peppery smoke on each draw

phrases: the blow drew blood from the corner of his mouth
she knew she'd drawn blood when the smile faded from his face
But I think they were really disappointed that nobody drew blood.
Of course since I was stitching after so long I drew blood and then I realized that I had forgotten all about the thimble once again.
But nobody would really want to fight if a vampire draws blood with no malice.
the government has drawn back from attempting reform
The genial married priest, who has six children, draws back from calling the people of the area pagans and denies he came from Uganda to convert.
I've been planning it, then drawing back from it, getting excited, then getting cold feet, but I finally handed in my resignation at work yesterday.
Both companies looked at floating two years ago but drew back in the face of falling share prices.
It draws back from the frenzied pursuit of marketing novelties and technological turnover and assumes the measured pace of humane and sustainable values.
origin: Old English dragan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch dragen and German tragen, also to draught.
